Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Dynamic Infared Filter of Vanadium Oxide Window Films for Improved Energy Efficiency
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase 1 project focuses on commercialization of stimuli responsive metal-insulator transitions in binary and ternary vanadium oxides. The remarkable tunability of the transition upon incorporation of substitutional and/or interstitial dopant ions has filled a key technological gap for their deployment as a dynamic infrared filter in thermally switchable laminates for fenestration (windows, doors, and skylights) and automobile glass. Much of the solar heat gain in structures occurs from the transmission of infrared energy (heat) through poorly insulating glass units. The stimuli responsive window laminates have several unique features to improve insulating glass units including: thermally switchable heat-blocking to heat-transmitting metal-insulator phase changes (or vice versa) without a substantial change in visible transmittance, adjustment of the transition temperature to meet the needs of different climatic regions, and incorporation of the nanomaterials into a flexible polymer matrix for high-end roll-to-roll retrofittable window laminates. The combination of this unique feature set enables our stimuli responsive window laminates to mitigate air-conditioning costs during warmer months while allowing the sun?s natural solar energy to warm interior spaces during cooler months without adversely affecting visible transparency.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is in using switchable window laminates to address critical needs in energy inefficient and outdated buildings, where more than 85% of buildings that exist today will exist in 20 years. This represents a relatively underutilized served market of size of $3.4 billion in the U.S. Much of the recent focus on energy efficiency relates to new buildings and deep renovations; yet the overwhelmingly poor energy efficiency of outdated buildings necessitates a facile low-cost retrofittable solution to reduce energy consumption and carbon dioxide emissions in the U.S. Our stimuli responsive laminates address this need and will contribute to U.S. competitiveness in green building materials and energy efficiency. The long term society impact will be more energy efficient buildings with a reduced carbon footprint, particularly in existing buildings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research phase I project optimized and refined the chemical process for synthesizing doped-vanadium oxides for use in next generation “smart” solar control products. Vanadium oxide undergoes a thermochromic metal-to-insulator phase transition that is accompanied by an abrupt and infrared selective change from transparent to reflective. In other words, the low temperature vanadium dioxide monoclinic phase (“off” mode) is infrared transparent and the high temperature vanadium dioxide rutile phase (“on” mode) is infrared reflective. The research effort explored doped-vanadium oxide compositional variants with a primary focus on tuning the metal-to-insulator phase transition temperature; thus, producing a thermally responsive and highly efficient solar control film. The synthetic and compositional space was systematically mapped producing near room temperature metal-to-insulator phase transitions. Furthermore, slurry and resin testing demonstrated stable dispersion formulations that integrated into industrial scale film coating processes. The doped-vanadium oxide polymer composite films (film prototypes) demonstrated proof of feasibility by substantially reducing infrared transmission across the “on” and “off” modes by more than 30% at a wavelength of 2500 nm.

 

The reversible change in infrared transmission through a transparent window has numerous solar control and energy saving benefits. For example, the effects of solar heating are frequently experienced on sunny days when the inside temperature of an auto can exceed 54°C (130°F). The problem is so acute that individuals use metallized dash board reflectors to mitigate the effect. The same solar heating that is such a nuisance in summer is very much welcome in winter. In buildings this tradeoff occurs when air-conditioning is switched for heating. The dynamic HVAC systems of buildings and automobiles require dynamic or smart solar control products to further improve efficiency. In terms of energy consumed, the Department of Energy (DOE) estimates that 50% of the energy produced in the US is used by buildings of which space cooling (13.1%), space heating (14.2%), and space lighting (25.5%) are the major contributors to building energy usage. Furthermore, approximately 80% of the buildings that exist today will exist in 20 years. Dimien’s transparent thermochromic smart windows have the potential to be easily retrofittable, installed in new construction, and highly energy efficient meeting the needs for next generation zero-energy buildings. If smart windows reach greater market adoption, the DOE predicts that approximately 1 quadrillion BTU’s of energy can be conserved in buildings alone.
